ABSTRACT - Hydrogen is considered the largest source of energy of the future and can be used by fuel cells in the transport sector in order to alleviate social and energy problems of the planet. However, the technologies needed to store, manufacture or distribute hydrogen are poorly consolidated and face the challenge of tackling the risks and high costs associated with them. In order to understand the main risks involved in the use of hydrogen and proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEM) in automotive vehicles, the preliminary hazard analysis (PHA) technique was used. It is known that equipment failures can lead to unacceptable loss of performance and that hydrogen is a flammable fuel whose leaks can be fatal. The scenarios evaluated, however, showed that this technology offers no more danger than the other ones in the market when the proper safeguards are in place. The PHA showed that severe fire events and explosions can be catastrophic, but they have low frequency and the indicated safeguard techniques can be very efficient. Except for collisions, which are unpredictable, other scenarios can have their damage avoided with a proper safety system.
Keywords: Hydrogen, vehicles, preliminary hazard analysis.

Introduction The rampant increase in the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, especially carbon dioxide, generated by the combustion of fossil materials, has caused widespread concerns. It is known that automotive vehicles are among the main contributors to global warming. Oil derivatives are the main fuels since the 19th century, when the first cars powered by internal combustion engines were invented. Its emissions involve air pollutants such as carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, nitrogen and sulfur oxides, particulate materials etc., which directly affect people's health, causing respiratory problems, environmental pollution, microclimate change and global warming.

There are currently more than 1.3 billion vehicles on the planet powered by fossil fuels. International agreements set deadlines and targets for reducing emissions. The Kyoto Protocol, for example, in force since 2005, already established the commitment of the countries involved in reducing greenhouse gas emissions (Goldenstein e Azevedo, 2006). The Hydrogen Economy expects the replacement of fuels that contain carbon by hydrogen, since its combustion releases water, avoiding air pollution and CO 2 emissions. Transport and storage limitations, however, in addition to the high cost of conversion into electricity, make it difficult to disseminate this proposal. By eliminating the bottlenecks of storage and distribution, it is possible to make hydrogen more accessible. According to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, more than 29% of its greenhouse gas emissions come from transportation (EPA, 2019). Cars powered by electricity are therefore very viable alternatives for reducing emissions and, consequently, reducing impacts on the environment.

The use of fuel cells in automotive vehicles, responsible for generating energy through hydrogen, is currently the main solution for emissions, since the oxidation of hydrogen is clean, its autonomy is significative longer than that of lithium battery electric cars and

has shorter charging time. However, because it is a recent technology and due to the peculiarities of hydrogen, it still needs improvement and it is necessary to study more accurately the potential risks involved in the use of this technology. Considered the largest source of energy of the future due to its availability, flexibility of production and use, hydrogen is currently used in refineries, in the chemical industry for the production of ammonia and methanol, in the steel industry, food industry and, more recently, in fuel cells for energy generation. Per unit of mass, hydrogen contains more energy than gasoline. It is light (its atom has only one proton and one electron), odorless, tasteless, and when burned with pure oxygen generates only water vapor and energy. It is usually found in the gaseous or combined phase, but in cryogenic systems it can also be found in liquefied form. Among the biggest challenges for large-scale hydrogen use is the lack of infrastructure, especially regarding distribution, storage and transportation limitations. In a gaseous state, it can be distributed through pipelines or cylinders and pressurized vessels. In liquid state, by cryogenic pipes and reservoirs, and in solid form, as metal hydrides or carbon nanostructures (Souza, 2009). For all distribution modalities there are considerable difficulties and need for development.

In order to ensure the technical and economic feasibility for the use of hydrogen as automotive fuel, efficient storage systems are required. In hydrogen-powered passenger cars, about 4-5 kg of hydrogen need to be stored, equivalent to 130-160 kWh. Tanks with this capacity can reach a range of 500 km, about 125 km with one kilo of gas. Although the energy density of hydrogen is high, its gravimetric density is low, making storage extremely difficult technically and thus the high cost. Heavy-duty tanks, heat management and safety valves are indispensable, in addition to short-term refueling capacity and low leakage risks (Fichtner, 2009). Innovations, among alternative energy sources, can be divided into electric and alternative fuel. Applied to automobiles, the former includes batteries and fuel cells, and alternative fuels would be mainly bioethanol and biodiesel. There are also hybrid fonts, which result from the combination of two different sources.

Electric motors have been considered alternatives to the transport sector since the last century, especially due to the absence of emissions and low noise. These electric vehicles, however, have some limitations. Batteries, in addition to being very heavy, have low energy storage capacity and long charging times. Purely electric vehicles take from 6 to 8 hours to be charged – when connected to a 120 V single-phase alternating current distribution network at a maximum power of 1.9 kW - or between 4 and 6 hours - when connected to a 240 V distribution network, up to 19.2 kW. Since the load represents an autonomy of 150 to 500 km, the loading time is an important restriction for the expansion of this technology (Van Balen et al., 2019).

In order to address the challenges of cost reduction, performance improvement and safety, a major focus of automakers today, studies have turned their attention to hydrogen as an energy source. It is stored in special tanks capable of supporting low temperatures and high pressure. When it is in operation, hydrogen comes out of the tank and encounters the air promoting an electrochemical reaction that releases water vapor and generates an electric current that powers the engine. The engine of cars with fuel cells is the same used in electric cars, however, because it is a gaseous chemical element, the supply is faster than conventional electric cars. Today, companies are investing in exploring new technologies that provide better performance and durability, such as the use of improved materials, better sealing to prevent leaks, optimization of rotor bead geometry, and higher pressure rates to improve efficiency.

Depending on the concentration and conditions of the environment, hydrogen, in the presence of oxygen, is highly flammable. Besides to the challenge of obtaining hydrogen in large quantities at low cost, it is important to know how to store it to avoid explosions —like the one that destroyed the German airship Hindenburg in 1937. To those who saw hope in the use of the hydrogen balloon as an efficient form of transport, the tragedy was a disappointment at the time, affecting public perception in general (Scientific American Brasil, 2018). More recently, in June 2019, two catastrophic events reinforced the need to overcome challenges: the explosion of a supply station in Norway and another in California.

The characteristics of hydrogen and the context of global expansion require an appropriate study of risks. Numerous formal reviews of safety techniques can be used, such as qualitative analyses such as HAZOP (Hazard and Operability Study), FMEA (Cause and Effect Analysis), Checklists and "What-If", as well as quantitative analyses such as Failure Tree (FTA) and semi-quantitative, such as Protection Layer Analysis (LOPA). In addition to those, Preliminary Hazard Analysis (PHA) is an important tool for analyzing risk scenarios and assessing the frequency and severity of the event.

A good risk management system includes activities that provide information to ensure safety in a sustainable way. It should be focused on several aspects, such as facilities projects, incident and accident investigation, inspections, maintenance, people training and preparation of detailed work procedures. It is known that not all processes require the same care and investments in security, so those at higher risk should be prioritized. PHA is a great tool to start this study and direct the focus that needs to be taken to mitigate or eliminate risks.

Objectives The main objective of this work is to develop a preliminary study of the risks involved in the use of hydrogen as an energy carrier for automotive vehicles. PHA technique was used to evaluate the main risks involved in the use of compressed hydrogen and proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEM) in automotive vehicles.

Experimental Preliminary Hazard Analysis The preliminary hazard analysis (PHA) is a broad initial study used in the early stages of an implementation project. It consists of identifying hazards, assessing vulnerability and then providing preventive measures. As its name says, a preliminary analysis is performed before a more complete study. It aims to select the main hazards and the main risk areas of a unit. In the PHA, hazards and risks are assessed considering that the equipment needed in the operation is already used normally and that the people involved in the process are trained. If there was an accident, the cause would therefore be different from these. The tool should always be developed with the participation of employees, since it forces reflection on the activity to be performed and ensures maximum information about it.

The most common way to perform a PHA is to identify possible accidental scenarios and classify them as frequency and severity if they occur. This step begins with the brainstorming with experts and exports on the subject. Frequency is a function of cause and effect, while severity is a function of effect only. In the case of the use of fuel cells, for example, the possibility of mechanical degradation of the polymermembrane of a proton-changing membrane fuel cell could cause the mixture of H 2 and O 2 in the cell's hood and cause an explosion. With PHA, we were able to map what could cause this degradation, how to detect it before causing a failure, and how to prevent it from happening, and know the severity of the risk involved in this scenario. The following steps are necessary for the preparation of an PHA (De Cicco and Fantazzini, 1994): a) Seek analogy or similarity with past experiences b) Establish the limits of action and delimit the system to be covered, as well as the function for which it is intended, those involved and how it will be developed.
c) Identify potential causes of direct and immediate injury, loss of value, equipment damage and loss of materials, i.e., determine the main accidental scenarios.
d) Review means of elimination or control of risks.
e) Search for possible damage restriction methods that are more efficient to eliminate damage generated in the event of loss of control over risks.

f) Indicate those responsible for the execution of preventive and/or corrective actions, as well as the activities to be developed. Conservative hypotheses are commonly used, imagining the most serious consequences, creating the most severe possible scenarios. The goal is to be prepared and prevent serious damage. This initial qualitative analysis has great importance in the investigation of new systems of high innovation and/or little known, especially when the experience in risks is deficient (Herbert, After detailed research, six accidental scenarios were defined and evaluated: hydrogen leakage in an open environment, hydrogen leakage in a confined environment, hydrogen leakage in a semi-confined environment, hydrogen leakage in a filling station, hydrogen tank rupture, and proton-changing membrane fuel cell failure. Each of these was deployed in different causes in order to classify the most frequent events and the necessary safeguards to avoid them. Then, some examples for each case were described. Since most hydrogen-powered cars are currently fueled by compressed hydrogen tanks, this was the storage form defined for all scenarios evaluated.

After the preparation of the PHA, the severity and frequency of each accident simulation were classified. Depending on the branch of the company and the level of commitment to safety, health and the environment, different definitions can be considered. According to Nolan (2008), severity can be divided between categories that rank potential events, according to the severity of injuries to workers, damage to facilities and the environment, impact on external areas and media interest. The frequency, in turn, can be classified according to the number of events per time.

Risk Matrix A risk matrix was built based on Nolan's recommendations and potential risk-causing events. It is essential to classify the risks involved in a process, because the way to classify them should indicate the degree of acceptability or tolerance of the risk, which is determined by the frequency and severity of the risk. It basically indicates whether the risk is critical, moderate, or non-critical. When the risk is unacceptable, you need to invest in reducing the severity or likelihood of it occurring. In many cases, redundancy is worked, which would be the application of extra devices or instruments in case of the main inactivity.

f) Event 6: Fuel cell failure - The mechanical degradation of the membrane, presented in the form of deformations, holes or tears, can be caused by defects originated in the membrane production process, material fatigue, errors in cell operation, failure in parameter control, high hydrogen flow, among others. When damaged, the unwanted mixture of O 2 and H 2 may occur, a sudden drop in pressure and performance (Oliveira, 2014).

- Chemical degradation of the membrane can cause loss of mechanical resistance and ionic conductivity. In cases where the catalyst is composed of metals other than platinum, the membrane may undergo chemical attack of hydroxyl and hydroperoxide radicals formed by reactions with impurities that may be present in the electrodes. The consequence is the fall in electrical potential and loss of cell performance. Monitoring of the potential and electrical current, automatic temperature control, hydrogen detection in the environment and chemical analysis of the water produced, such as a pH meter, for example, are alternatives to detect and control these failures.

-Thermal degradation occurs when the proton-changing membrane undergoes morphological changes when subjected to temperatures above 100 ºC, which cause dryness and weakening of the membrane, as well as ruptures in the polymer chains and consequent reduction of conductivity. It is possible to visually detect some degrees of thermal degradation, since the membrane acquires brown coloration.

- Crack of bipolar plates can be caused by sudden variations in the system and wear of the materials that compose it. Leakage of reagent gases through the plate and increased resistance to electronic driving are the main damage in this scenario. The necessary safeguards would be installation of sensors for H 2 detection, continuous monitoring of current and electrical potential of the cell, leakage noise, observation of condensed steam on the surface of the graphite plate.

- The obstruction of the flow channels can be occurred by some failure in the control of parameters or inadequate configuration of the channels. It can cause water buildup and dilution of gases in the electrodes, impairing cell performance. Continuous monitoring of the current and electrical potential of the cell, as well as the temperature and flow of gases are controls that can indicate the problem. - Oxidation and consequent degradation of current collecting plates can cause the reduction of electron flow by the external circuit of the cell and reduction of the rates of electrochemical reactions. To prevent oxidation events, the application of protections can mitigate or slow down the problem, such as the application of gold layer of the metal surface, for example. Unlike events 1 to 5, the last event describes some situations of proton-exchange membrane fuel cell failures in vehicular applications. In general, the failures of its components cannot be detected immediately or diagnosed without disassembling the cell, however, it is known that they can lead to an unacceptable loss of performance, which can cause unscheduled downtime during vehicle movement and cause accident (Barbir et al., 2016). Thus, the analysis of the risks of loss of performance of fuel cell equipment becomes fundamental.
In order to classify the severity and risks of each macro event of the Preliminary Hazard Analysis, an adaptation was made to the Nolan classification (2008):

• Category I: Potential to cause minor injury to passengers and drivers and minor damage to the car and the environment. It does not generate impact in areas outside the vehicle and does not interest the media.

• Category II: Small lesions requiring medication and dressings. It can generate small disturbance in the neighboring population, such as odor and noise, and may cause negative reaction and possible interest in the media. • Category III: Potential to cause permanent injury to people and possible fatality. Great damage to the environment and the vehicle(s) involved, generating interest in the local media and negative reaction of the population. • Category IV: More than one fatality or permanent injury. It is catastrophic and has the potential to cause irreparable or high-cost damage to the environment or nearby facilities. Significant disturbance in the neighboring population, property damage, injuries or temporary diseases. Intense negative reaction from the local population and interest in the national media. The frequency can be classified as follows:
• Category A: There are no reports of having occurred in vehicles of the same category.
• Category B: Very unlikely, but possible. There is historical report of having already occurred in vehicles of the same category or similar events.
• Category C: It is likely to occur sometimes in vehicles or similar situations.
• Category D: May occur several times during the life of the vehicle.

The most critical scenario concerns the explosion of the tank in an environment confined by increased pressure and consquent hydrogen leakage. The release of all gas present in the tank in a confined environment such as a garage, tunnel or the interior of the vehicle itself, in the presence of spark or any other source of ignition, would have the potential to generate an explosion. A very serious scenario would be the explosion caused by increased pressure during supply. In this case, a secondary explosion could be generated due to the presence of hydrogen in other storage tanks, making the event catastrophic. The normal situation would be for the tank safety valve to open upon reaching given pressure and release hydrogen into the atmosphere. In this case, the flame intensity would increase, but the tank explosion would be avoided, so the consequences would be smaller Hydrogen as a source of fire or explosion can come from fuel storage, fuel lines or fuel cell. The fuel cell poses the lowest risk, although hydrogen and oxygen are separated by a very thin polymer membrane. In the event of a membrane rupture, hydrogen and oxygen would come into contact, but in this case, the fuel cell would lose its potential in a way easily detected by a control system, which should trigger the disconnection of supply lines (OLIVEIRA, 2014).

The operating temperature of the fuel cell (60° to 90° C) is low enough to be a source of thermal ignition. Possible but unlikely ignition conditions would be the combination of hydrogen and oxygen on the catalyst surface. However, the potential damage would be quite limited, since only a small amount of hydrogen is present in the fuel cell and fuel supply lines.

The main risks associated with a hydrogen leak are the possibility of developing a flammable or explosive atmosphere. In some cases, such as what occurs in an open environment, it is concluded that the possibility of explosion is negligible, given the physical- chemical characteristics of hydrogen, which has much lower density than that of air, facilitating its dispersion in the environment. However, the same may not occur in confined environments.

Most accidental releases are at room temperature, so ignition is unlikely, even when released at high pressure. However, it is possible that some form of electrostatic charging generates a spontaneous ignition.

In general, most predicted failures can be avoided and consequences minimized by preventing leaks through an appropriate system design and equipment, with tolerance to shocks and vibrations. In addition, they also contribute to prevention: installation of pressure relief devices to protect lines, installation of additional safety valves, leak detection by high-efficiency detectors, prevention of ignition through automatic disconnection of the battery or devices capable of generating electrical sparks, designing physically separate supply lines from all electrical devices, batteries, motors and wires and inclusion of active and passive ventilation system for hydrogen exhaust.

Conclusions With the increasing global energy demand, the search for an environmentally friendly fuel is a necessity. As mentioned, hydrogen is an efficient and clean fuel that meets this need, but has limitations on its distribution, storage and, especially, safety. Some unfortunate accidents during history do not favor hydrogen's reputation which makes public trust a restriction on its development in the short term.

Preliminary Hazard Analysis applied to hydrogen fuel cell-powered automotive vehicles showed that serious events are generally not very frequent. In addition, the safeguards indicated can be very efficient in order to avoid accidents. Except for the collisions, which are unpredictable, all other scenarios can have their damage avoided with a proper safety system, such as the intake of hydrogen detectors, tanks with pressure relief device, isolation or shutdown valve and pressure regulation valve. In addition, as vehicles in general are often stored inside garages and travel through tunnels, care about the difficulty of dispersal within these areas should be taken. Inside vehicles, if enough openings are provided, the ease of hydrogen dispersion would ensure a state of equilibrium in a short time, softening ignition risks.

Although it does not address the most critical scenarios, flaws in the proton-exchange membrane fuel cell also involve important risks. In this case, the worst-case scenarios were considered in which the correct hydrogen path within the cell is compromised and can cause leakage and/or in. Then, the most critical scenarios would be those in which the total loss of performance of the cell could cause the total stop of operation of the vehicle and may end in accidents.

In order to avoid virtually all the mentioned events, strict control in the quality of the production process of the fuel cell and hydrogen tanks, training personnel responsible for their operation and maintenance are indispensable. Regular inspections and reviews should be carried out to predict fatigue events and the need to exchange parts and materials. Some of the controls mentioned, mainly involving visual and sound detection are not effective in vehicular applications, so alarms and sensors should be used. Although not all researchers and potential users agree, the elaborate risk matrices allow us to say that today hydrogen is no more dangerous than any other fuel. Recent research conducted by several organizations corroborates this conclusion and reinforces that hydrogen should not be discarded from the current energy matrix for safety reasons. To perform a complete feasibility analysis, however, other criteria would need to be considered, such as hydrogen production and the distribution network.
